preqs: 24 points of level one units, which includes 6 points from BIO units or one of ATS1301, ATS1309, ATS1310, BMS1011 or BMS1021.For Bachelor of Environmental Engineering and associated double degree students only: ENE1621 Environmental engineering and BIO2040 Conservation biology will be required as either prerequisite or corequisite units.

rules.ruleString: For COURSE_CODE NOT IN {1253, 4609, 4615, 4616, 4643, 4644, 4645, 4646, E3001, E3002, E3003, E3005, E3007} Do (Must have passed 24 (I/W) credit points at levels {1} and  Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {ATS1301, ATS1309, ATS1310, BIO1%, GES1%}) Otherwise Must have passed 24 (I/W) credit points at levels {1}

For COURSE_CODE IN {1253, 4609, 4615, 4616, 4643, 4644, 4645, 4646, E3001, E3002, E3003, E3005, E3007} Do (Any passed co-req (I/W) unit in {ENE1621} and Any passed co-req (I/W) unit in {BIO2040}) Otherwise true

For COURSE_CODE NOT IN {1253, 4609, 4615, 4616, 4643, 4644, 4645, 4646, E3001, E3002, E3003, E3005, E3007} Do (Must have passed 24 (I/W) credit points at levels {1} and  Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {ATS1301, ATS1309, ATS1310, BIO1%, BMS1011, BMS1021, GES1%}) Otherwise Must have passed 24 (I/W) credit points at levels {1}

description: This unit is an introduction to ecology; the scientific study of the interactions between organisms and their environment. Ecology and biodiversity forms the foundation for understanding conservation and the management of genetics, species and ecosystem diversity. The approach taken is to address core ecological theory, but with an emphasis on contemporary management issues and applications. Topics include the scope and approaches of ecological enquiry; abiotic and biotic factors determining distributions; population growth and regulation; species interactions; patterns and maintenance of biodiversity; food web analysis; disturbance and succession; and production ecology and nutrient cycling. Particular emphasis is placed on integrating ecological processes across spatial and temporal scales. Practical work will be completed via a field excursion together with in-laboratory practical sessions.
